Primary prevention consists of reducing the only known environmental factor responsible for melanoma: UV exposure.

This means encouraging photoprotection by limiting exposure during hours of strong sunlight and giving priority to clothing protection.


Secondary prevention aims to improve prognosis through early detection of melanoma. This involves training doctors, who must know how to examine their patient's integument in its entirety, spot suspicious lesions and refer to an expert correspondent in case of doubt.

It is essential to combine this with information and education on early melanoma screening for carers (nurses, pharmacists, physiotherapists, etc.), the general population and those most at risk of melanoma.

question.title: Prevention of Melanoma
question.description: What is the primary goal of primary prevention for melanoma?

option_a.title: Early detection of melanoma
option_a.description: Early detection of melanoma is the primary goal of primary prevention.

option_b.title: Reducing UV exposure
option_b.description: Reducing UV exposure is the primary goal of primary prevention.

option_c.title: Improving prognosis through early detection
option_c.description: Improving prognosis through early detection is the primary goal of secondary prevention.

option_d.title: Increasing melanoma screening
option_d.description: Increasing melanoma screening is the primary goal of primary prevention.

correct_option.title: B
correct_option.description: The correct letter indicating the primary goal of primary prevention.
